There was an interesting paper at last year's WS-REST:

K. R. Page, D. C. D=
e Roure, and K. Martinez, =93REST and Linked Data: a match
made for domain =
driven development?,=94 in Proceedings of the 2nd
International Workshop on=
 RESTful Design (WS-REST 2011), 2011, pp. 22-25.

http://ws-rest.org/2011/p=
roc/a5-page.pdf


I personally distinguish between the traditional "Semanti=
c Web" and "Linked
Data". Linked Data, for me, is just interlinked structur=
ed data and, as
that, a great match to RESTful systems.

I think most of th=
e "debate/mismatch/battle/whatever between REST and Linked
Data" stems from=
 the AI-heavy history of the Semantic Web efforts. So
developers are often =
afraid to use it/learn it - even though heaps of them
are using those techn=
ologies without even knowing it (think Facebook's Open
Graph annotations). =
I usually use the term Semaphobia to describe this fear
:-)


--
Markus Lan=
thaler
@markuslanthaler

> From: rest-discu=

a
> 
> I'll have a stab at it..
> 
> Linked Data is=A0concerned=A0with usin=
g hypertext to construct an
> intelligible=A0graph from the web that is pub=
licly available and can be
> analysed/queried.
> 
> REST is concerned with =
using hypertext to expose applications so that
> their evolution can be man=
aged efficiently over time.
> 
> Basically, they use hypertext as a means t=
o different ends. REST is
> about directing the flow of the web's applicati=
ons, LD is about
> establishing a structure to the web's data.
> 
> One imp=
ortant LD-related technology is RDF, although it's not the only
> way to do=
 LD it does seem to have unearthed some of the fundamental
> differences be=
tween LD and REST, so I'll share my perspective on that:
> 
> RDF, in the q=
uest for web-intelligibility, does not seem to cope very
> well with the am=
biguous and messy reality of The Web. This has led to
> a lot of controvers=
y and demands from the RDF community for solutions
> to problems that appar=
ently don't exist for REST or anyone else
> outside of 'RDF land' - a good =
example of a this is range-14. This has
> produced lots of long-winded and =
confused philosophical debate, but
> one of my favourite insights is a post=
 from 2002 by Roy:
> 
> http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2002Jul=
/0090.html
> 
> Cheers,
> Mike
>
